Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Andrew A. Campbell of the University of Tennessee at Knoxville to conduct a research project, entitled "Impact of electric bicycle sharing on transportation choices in Beijing," during the summer of 2012 at Tsinghua University in Beijing, People's Republic of China. The host scientist is Professor Xinmiao Yang, Institute of Transportation Engineering, Department of Civil Engineering.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is a well-timed contribution to the body of knowledge addressing how bicycle sharing affects transportation choices. The city of Beijing has announced plans to install a 50,000 bicycle fleet by 2015. Previous studies have found that systems using standard bicycles can both complement and compete with public transit. However, no known research has explored the idea of including motorized electric bicycles in a bike sharing system.T This research is relevant to cycling-friendly American communities. By reducing the effort required to propel a bicycle, electric bikes have the potential to open cycling to new demographics.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the intersection of two major global transportation trends: the rise of shared public bicycle systems (bikeshare), and the rapid adoption of electric-assist bicycles (e-bikes) in China. Public bikeshare is a system where a user checks out a bike from a secure station, rides it to the destination, and locks it at a new station for someone else to use. It is the world’s fastest growing mode of public transportation, with the global fleet approaching half a million bikes. This new mode of transit is truly a global phenomenon, with new systems blossoming in major and minor cities across western and eastern countries. E-bikes are bicycles or pedal-powered-scooters that incorporate a battery and electric motor to assist the rider in moving the vehicle. In China, the number of e-bikes on the road has grown from virtually nil to well over 100 million in the last 15 years, constituting the fastest uptake of a transportation mode in human history. China is the world’s leader in both public bikeshare and private e-bike growth. Technology and adoption trajectories suggest that large system of public shared e bikes (e-bikeshare) will emerge in China. Against this backdrop, I went to Beijing to investigate the role that bikeshare and e-bikeshare would play in one of the world’s great megacities.

The study’s goal was to identify the use and impact of bikeshare and e-bikeshare systems in Beijing. Who would use the systems and for what types of trips? How would bikeshare and e-bikeshare impact the existing transportation system? To do so, I recruited and managed a team of 20 undergraduates from Tsinghua, China’s top technical university, to conduct a survey throughout the city’s core urban districts. The survey asked questions about the factors that influence the choice to use shared bikes: distance, cost, weather, environmental conditions, travel habits, and demographics. The data were used to build a behavior model that predicts the probability that someone will choose bikeshare or e-bikeshare for a certain trip.

Between the survey statistics and the behavior model, we learned that significant distinctions exist between how bikeshare and e-bikeshare would be used and who would use them. Bikeshare is most appealing for short trips during comfortable weather conditions. E-bikeshare is preferred for longer trips and better suited to uncomfortable weather conditions, especially the summer heat in Beijing. This is intuitive since the e-bike’s electric motor reduces effort for the rider. While bikeshare has broad appeal, e-bikeshare is attractive to a distinct socio-demographic group: young males with lower levels of education and income.  We find that both shared bike modes would draw most of their users from “green” modes: walking, private biking, and public transit. All though neither mode competes strongly with the subway, e-bikeshare is a very attractive substitute for short to medium length bus trips. Our study also revealed that Beijing citizens make strategic transportation decisions to reduce their exposure to bad air quality. This is a novel finding that has motivated ongoing investigation of the topic.

These results have important implications for the implementation of bikeshare and e-bikeshare in Beijing. Bikeshare will be most popular in highly dense areas where trip lengths are short. This best describes the commercial and entertainment zones of downtown Beijing, areas that are already very friendly to cyclists and pedestrians and well served by public transit. It is likely that bikeshare will do little to curb motorization rates in Beijing, but will rather shift users between low impact modes like walking and riding personal bikes.
